11.3km altitude using the sounds vs visuals and assumptions.  27.3 seconds from RUD to Boom.  At 340m/s that is approx 9.3km away from LZ.  Using the view (lake, condos, tennis court) this placed you at a resort that google says is 9.5km from LZ.  Then using MECO at apogee, the sound takes 45 seconds.  But at 12km up, sound is 295m/s (not a linear relationship).  So average speed is approx 325m/s putting SN8 at 14.6 km from the PSPBR hotel.  Using Pythagoras (A^2 + B^2 = H^2), this then puts SN8 height at 11.3km (with a lot of assumptions)

This video perfectly captures my thoughts watching the live-stream with the official tracking. Things are cutting off. Are they going up? Down? Sideways? Is it exploding now? Was it even flopping at Apogee after it was just hovering and doing power-lateral-slides? Oh boy - it looks like it is working. Followed by "you do not manage to relight the engines SpaceX - then they did that and really flipped. Just before the engine exhaust turned neon-green. Which is the wrong colour - as everything went gloriously orange while I observed that my own mission profile had made me stand up and jumping up and down harder than I did in the 90s watching "Rage against the machine" live on stage.


It was the most glorious high-altitude test-flight ever (being aware that when the first hot-air balloon went up more than 500 feet probably was bonkers to watch at the time - I sure watched the parachute test by a crazy person jumping off the Eiffel tower to test the aero-breaking capabilities of some tailored bed-sheets flapping around - humans are awesome, Franz Reichelt, even if tailors did not always get aerodynamics completely right)

I mean - SpaceX knows how to land rockets screaming through the atmosphere with flamy end down. They managed to belly-float this dad-bod down at strolling pace and turn the flamy end down - after power-sliding a rocket laterally at 30000 ft for fun for an extra minute.

Glorious. And I think they will nail it this year. The current question is "how quickly can they learn to slow down this chunky piece of metal from orbital speeds down by air friction without melting it during re-entry - without skipping off said fluid"?

But when it did that sudden smooth sweep to right it's self I was amazed and I quit breathing. Was it going to land too?
All three engines fired up. One quit, OK, two still OK. (It is going to land)...
At that last minute engine #2 quit, and the plume from #1 turned green.
It still was trying to land, it set down, (maybe too fast?) BOOM-WHOOSH! Yep...
But looking back, who cares?
